title.narrative: Life-Saving Trauma Care Services to Conflict Affected Population in Kunduz, Badakhshan and Logar provinces

description.narrative:
Save the children is currently implementing a CHF funded First Aid Trauma Posts (FATPs) project in Kunduz province. In this proposed project, Save the Children will enter into a sub-agreement with Care of Afghan Families (CAF) to provide trauma care to the conflict affected population including first aid, triage, stabilization, emergency management and referral in the 9 districts broken down to 6 districts in Kunduz, 2 in Badakhshan and 1 district in Logar provinces.
Save the Children aims to build on the current project and will continue to provide trauma care to the conflict affected population in six districts of Kunduz province. CAF will establish two stand alone FATPs in Tagab and Raghistan districts of Badakhshan province and one stand alone FATP in Mohammad Agha district of Logar province to cover 126 villages.
Taghab, Raghistan and Mohammad Agha are amongst 24 priority districts identified by the Health Cluster for the 2016 second standard allocation by CHF. Based on the recent needs assessment conducted in August 2016, the data trend in the last five months (March – July 2016) indicated a gradual and constant increase in the number of conflict affected casualties in Kunduz province. The recent volatile security situation has caused such trend of conflict related casualties with substantial increase in trauma morbidity and mortality in the conflict affected vulnerable population. Considering the new emergency situation and in line with Health Cluster Objective 1: “Provision of effective trauma care and mass casualty management to conflict affected people.” There is a crucial need for the continuation of life saving first aid trauma care in five existing FATPs located in Archi, Imam Sahib, Khan Abad, Ali Abad and Qala-i-Zal districts (one per district) of Kunduz province. In Chardara district of Kunduz province, FATP of the Comprehensive Health Center (CHC) will be relocated to Joma Bazar Basic Health Center (BHC) due to the increased number of trauma cases. FATPs will continue to facilitate stabilization, emergency management and referrals of conflict affected casualties from frontline to the referral health facilities.
Save the Children in collaboration with CAF has been implementing the Basic Package of Health Services (BPHS) in Kunduz and CAF is the lead BPHS implementer in Badakhshan and Logar provinces. This structure will ensure coordinated actions between FATPs, BPHS and referral facilities between the two organizations.
The proposed action will reach 50,559 direct beneficiaries including 20,209 women and girls. The timeline for such action is from 1 October 2016 till 30 September 2017. Badakhshan and Logar provinces from 1 October 2016 while Kunduz would be from 1 November 2016, following completion of the current CHF funded project. Save the Children and CAF will continue to implement this project in coordination with all relevant actors at the national, provincial and community levels to ensure effective and timely management of trauma cases.
